Message:
It was an ordinary day,
just like any other.

I still remember the smell
of the stew I made
together with Mom.
The sounds from Dad
rustling his newspaper.

Then, the sudden,
harsh knocks pounding
on our door.

Mom had me hide in the closet.
“Don’t come out,
no matter what happens,”
she whispered in my ear.

I can still recall the way
her hands trembled.

I’ll never forget
what I saw next,
as I peered through
the crack in that closet.

Our front door was broken down,
and men in black robes stormed in.
They dragged Mom and Dad away.

My parents never called my name
or glanced in my direction,
even until the very end.

I was terrified. I wanted to cry.
I wanted to scream
for them to stop.

But, I swallowed down
every emotion, until my throat
felt like it would bleed.
I locked them all up,
deep inside my heart.
The next morning, I saw them.

My parents, hanging in
the town square.

Two years have
passed since then.
And yet, I still feel like
I’m hiding inside that closet.
